posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: If a team were able to hypothetically switch gear ratios while accelerating, they could obtain both low-end torque and high top speed, which would’ve been overpowered for games like Crescendo, where players have long open-field cycles but also face defense, requiring additional force. Obviously, this would come with drawbacks such as weight, complexity, and robustness, but could there be a world where this is a viable strategy for a top team?

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked: I know a couple teams have experimented with it; I forget who was showing that off in their pit at Championship 2022. If there was that much of an edge, I feel like someone would’ve mopped the floor with the rest of us by now.
2557 did so in 2023, moved to COTS swerve in 2024.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked:
1640 has done custom shifting and CVT swerve modules quite a few times.

1640, Sab-BOT-age, is proud to present our 2020 CVT Swerve Module. Our 2017-2019 CVT swerve module was designed to enhance functionality on top of our standard swerve module, which underwent regular updates since its introduction in 2010. While this provided significant success, it didn't optimize the CVT implementation effectively. Over the past two years, we've dedicated countless hours to redesigning our swerve module from the ground up.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: From a swerve history standpoint, this thread has some of the attempts and discussions of the (dis)advantages through the years. Curious if anyone has a working concept for a shifting swerve drive they’d be willing to share. We really utilized shifting gearboxes on our differential chassis. A fellow mentor brought it up to me at the Idaho Regional. My personal opinion: in the age of brushless, shifting gearboxes are somewhat defeated. Furthermore, with swerve “slow is smooth, smooth is fast”, in other words—for most games it isn’t a pure power question, rather one of precision.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked: Mark says that frequently, and do several others in the 2767 cluster. In the factory, we value the people who get a job done in minimum time; we actively discourage running up and down the aisles.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
In theory, there is a slight edge in games with full-field sprints due to optimal gearing, which limits performance by motor torque rather than wheel traction at lower speeds. This could result in a 10-20% improvement in sprint times. Additionally, it conserves battery energy compared to fixed-gearing setups. While this approach seems superior to the 8-motor swerve systems used in 2023, teams that implemented it often faced challenges.

In FIRST Robotics Competition, every opportunity comes with trade-offs. Teams typically lose matches either because their drivetrains aren’t fast enough or because their mechanisms lack reliability. Prioritizing efforts where they’ll have the most impact is key.

Practically, a variable-speed drivetrain accelerates faster than its fixed-speed counterpart with the same maximum speed. However, limiting acceleration to enhance drivability and stability often negates those benefits.

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked: You also need to consider the coefficient of friction between the wheels and the carpet. Under high-torque conditions (like trying to push another robot out of the way) you will reach a limit where additional torque at the wheels doesn’t make you move the robot but instead causes the wheels to spin in place. Once that happens, more torque just makes you burn holes in the carpet more effectively.

posts.name: Kooper
posts.cooked: Slow is smooth, smooth is fast. This is basically our lead mentor’s motto for everything robotics.

Team 5687 implemented this in 2024. They were very effective at navigating defense using their designs. The Outliers presented their 2024 robot Barry, built around innovative swerves utilizing a ball shifter actuated by a pneumatic cylinder. The gear ratios were set at 6.86:1 for low gear and 4.51:1 for high gear,

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: In the factory we value the people who get a job done in minimum time; we actively dislike running up and down the aisles. It would be cool if we could improve the robot's acceleration to make it smoother and reduce the risk of tipping.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: Well, I mean, the mechanical lead has to deal with it.
